  1533. I bought my first RV544 after a \\"blow-dry 101\\" class with my stylist. Noted features: 1) ionic, 2) tourmaline, 3) concentrator attachment that has a narrow opening. DO NOT get rid of your concentrator attachment when you buy a new blow dryer! I have very straight, flat hair so a diffuser is useless for me, but the concentrator is essential. It builds body and volume. Some dryers have a funneling \\"concentrator\\" that is so fat it could hardly be concentrating anything. Look for a slim opening. This dryer has it. Another favorite feature: it's VERY lightweight. I style my hair from start to finish with my blow dryer, no curling/straightening tools, just the dryer and 2 brushes. Technique is important. I have a great stylist who taught me this. Anyway the light weight is great both for use and for travel. And, the attachments snap on and pivot easily in a groove on the end of the blower. This is important because a dryer that has a concentrator that just fits over the end but doesn't snap in place will make you FURIOUS. I am talking about the concentrator either blowing off mid-process, or being so tight that you can't get it off nor can you pivot it. I have carpal tunnel syndrome and it is very painful to try to adjust the concentrator. This one is so very easy. I have owned 2 of these dryers and I'm ready to purchase my 3rd. One of my daughters took over #1, someone burned a hole in the concentrator of #2, and to replace it I bought an expensive salon dryer thinking price meant value. That's the one that has been driving me nuts. I'm going to retire the pricey dryer to the \\"emergency\\" drawer and buy this one again. If you have read this review and are interested in technique, check out this link: [...]
  1534. I prefer to dry my hair on the low setting and was disappointed to find that the low setting on this model wasn't low. Even with the diffuser it just didn't suit my needs.
  1535. I'm currently on my second one of these. It's a great, powerful hair dryer, and I'll probably keep buying one when this one eventually fails! I had my first one for about a year, when it suddenly decided only to work when the business end was pointed down. Which, okay, I can work with, but I didn't hesitate to buy another one to replace it. It's powerful, not too loud, not too heavy or unwieldy, and it actually gets hot. Some other reviewers feel that it gets too hot, but I think it's just right, though it was certainly a change to use a new, more powerful dryer after using a practical but underpowered foldable model for years. The attachments are great, and I got a little tutorial from the amazing lady who cuts my hair on how to use the diffuser attachment, which was super helpful. This is definitely a bang-for-your-buck sort of product -- maybe it's not the flashiest, maybe it won't last long enough to be passed down to your grandkids, but in the meantime, it does exactly what you want it to. No bells and whistles here, but it's a solid little thing that can really do its job. And you can't beat that price!

  1557. Ok, that's not true. Ions are completely, 100% real. But the real question is whether or not they have magical powers to make your hair soft, silky, and extra shiny. Well, here's the answer: It's all marketing BS. Seriously, what kind of ions are they? Are they positively charged or negatively charged? The lack of detail offered does not inspire confidence.<br /><br />But aside from the ions, this device effectively expels hot air. When I turn it on and point it at my hair when it is wet, my hair dries. When I use the air focusing attachment in conjunction with a round brush, my hair is straightened. When I use the diffuser it's not straight. But it's also not pretty. I'm pretty sure I'm using it wrong or something.<br /><br />In all seriousness however, this hair dryer is perfectly effective. Don't waste your money on a more expensive hair dryer unless it comes with robotic arms which style your hair for you. This is a heating element and a fan, an incredibly simple device.<br /><br />Initially when I began my quest for a new hair dryer I was overwhelmed by all the choices, and I began doing research on what makes a hair dryer good. I even made a spreadsheet! I began googling and was told that there are multiple factors which are important: Ions, ceramic heating element, type of motor, and wattage.<br /><br />1. Ions: I've already discussed these in the beginning of the post. But for further clarification, I'll include information from a more reputable source than someone who calls herself \\"CatMonkey\\".<br /><br /> \\"How do \\"ionic\\" hair dryers affect the hair, short-term and long term?<br /> In the short term, the ions produced by an ionic hair dryer help reduce static electricity. Ordinary blow dryers tend to produce static electricity. Having extra charged particles (ions) in the air allows any built-up electrical charge (static electricity) to be transferred through the air to other nearby surfaces. This doesn't have much effect, since the \\"frizzy\\" effects of static electricity fade within a few minutes anyway. Coating the hair with gel or some kind of conductive conditioner would have a much stronger and lasting effect than ions, which only exist while the hair dryer is running. In the long term, ions are more reactive than other molecules, so they probably cause the hair and/or natural oils to be oxidized and the hair to become more brittle. But this is probably a smaller effect than the use of conditioners (good) or hot air (bad). More worrisome is that ionic generators generate ozone, which is good high in the atmosphere but bad here at ground level. Ozone contributes to smog and can cause lung irritation.\\" Source: University of California Santa Barbara: Science Line ([...]<br /><br />So, long story short: Ions might have some effect, but it's negligible compared to a good conditioner, and ionic generators generate ozone. I couldn't find a hair dryer without \\"ionic technology\\" but skip the ones with an ionic generator and buy a fancy conditioner instead.<br /><br />2. Ceramic heating element: I had a hard time finding a hair dryer that wasn't ceramic. Whether or not this makes it better or worse is unknown to me. Supposedly it helps the hair dryer heat more evenly. I'm calling BS on this too.<br /><br />3. Type of motor: Supposedly the type of motor makes a difference, whether it's AC or DC. For this I asked an electrical engineer if this could possibly make a difference. He was very confused as to why I was asking him such a dumb question because there would be zero impact on it. \\"FFS CatMonkey, it's a heating element and a fan. It's not complicated. Why are you wasting so much time on this? Don't you have an organic chemistry midterm tomorrow? The type of current doesn't matter at all.\\"<br /><br />4. Wattage: Some websites said that higher wattage meant higher heat, others said that it wasn't a valid indicator of heat output as there was significant variation between high wattage dryers and heat output.<br /><br />Now we've come to the end, I evaluated those four factors and eventually realized that there are really only a few criteria which are important to me. Cord length, included attachments, and weight. This dryer has a nice long cord, two attachments, and it's not super heavy. Oh, and it's less than $20. Perfect!w we've come to the end, I evaluated those four factors and eventually realized that there are really only a few criteria which are important to me. Cord length, included attachments, and weight. This dryer has a nice long cord, two attachments, and it's not super heavy. Oh, and it's less than $20. Perfect!

Had I not thrown it to the floor when I saw the first sparks, I would have been injured like another reviewer said happened to his wife. Considering that I owned a Conair for almost 10 years and a Vidal Sassoon for over 15 years with no such problems, I can no longer recommend this blow dryer and will not purchase another Revlon in the future.

  1592. I had this hair dryer for a few years but it recently just died when I dropped it on my bathroom floor. The hair dryer functioned OK and you'll notice noticeably less hair static and frizz compared to non-ionic driers. However, I suggest that you consider paying a little more for a better Conair's 225NP 1875 watt Tourmaline Ceramic hair dryer. I always found Revlon's rear vent frustratingly difficult to clean, and I actually had to use vacuum attachments to clean out the accumulated lints and fuzz on the grill. Conair's is a simple flip out grill with a smooth filter that I can simply wipe off easy. The Revlon dryer frequently sparked internally while in use for no apparent reason, and it was much louder and blowed noticeably weaker than Conair's that I recently got as a replacement. Do yourself a favor and spend a bit extra for an appliance you'll use daily for next several years.

  1682. I purchased this back in Aug '08 from Amazon and I have finally gotten around to writing a review and it is definitely positive. This replaced my old Vidal Sassoon which had lasted years but the screen got loose and caught in the fan and it was done. I searched and finally settled on this. I couldn't believe that it actually DID dry my hair faster like the other reviews had said, and also without feeling like my hair is frying and, remarkably, it does feel quite soft compared to my old dryer. My hair is medium to long and extremely thick (fine hair but a lot of it) so it still is amazing how fast this dries my hair- </= 5 minutes. I never thought I'd care about that cold blast shot but it has come so handy as I do use hot rollers quite often. This is also the quietest hair dryer I've ever had. A lower softer rumble from my old one. I loved this hair dryer so much, when I saw the same model on sale at a local drug store chain later that year, I bought one for our family's weekend place. That's when I noticed a HUGE difference. The second one I bought was very loud, and sounded like it was working too hard. I called the manufacturer and they couldn't explain it. That's when my husband and I looked at both and noticed that the one I bought from Amazon had 4 FAN BLADES and the one I bought from the drug store had 7 FAN BLADES. The customer service rep said that isn't the reason why it sounded so bad but my husband and I were convinced and my husband is an engineer. So, I went back to the drug store and found one out of the bunch that had the 4 FAN BLADES. Voila! It works as wonderfully as the first one I bought. So, my advice is: Be sure to get the one with 4 FAN BLADES. I don't know how you'd do that with Amazon, though. I strongly feel there is a remarkable difference in loudness and performance. This is an excellent hair dryer with the 4 fan blades. It's still going strong over two years later with daily use. The second one I bought isn't usedas often but is in same excellent condition. UPDATE 1/8/11- thumbs down! It seems I jinxed myself writing the above glowing review. My hairdryer is slowly dying. Its GFI plug kept tripping a couple of days and now my dryer is running on a low speed while on the high switch, the low switch is barely running at all. Still have heat, hair is still drying but obviously I need a new dryer. I just read a recent review on here that says she experienced the same problem, but within a matter of 2 months. My dryer got a little over 2 years. It was a great dryer but now if it is as claimed by the other reviewer that this is a common problem of it tripping and motor dying, I cannot really give a good review considering my old Vidal Sassoon lasted many years, if not for the loosened fan screen getting caught in the blades and ruining it.
  1683. Overall, I like this hairdryer. It has good power and I like the attachments. I like having the warm/hot heat settings and the high/low blower settings.<br /><br />My only complaint is that if you want to use the cool temperature, you have to continuously hold down the cool button. It's not a toggle. On my old Revlon hair dryer that this one replaced, if I clicked on the cool button, the cool stayed on until I clicked the cool again. That was nice for when I was doing some finishing with cool air.<br /><br />Overall, this was a good hair dryer for the price.

The last two dryers I had started putting out sparks and one time burned my hand. When it happened the first time, it was after using the dryer for about two years so I thought maybe it was defective or just old. However, this morning it happened again and it was from the cord on the part right underneath the dryer. If you see customer pics, that's exactly what mine looked like. I'm now going to go with a different brand of dryer.
  1690. I love this dryer! It is so much lighter then my old clunker. Also the attachable nozzle is great for getting deep into your hair and drying your roots and whatnot. The heat settings are adequate and the beast part is that you can bring this with you to work or the gym because it wont weigh you down!
  1691. After a really long search I kept finding good reviews on this Revlon RV544 tourmaline ionic lightweight and for that price I had to give a try, OMG it is really amazing I dried my hair in record time and the result ....., I had no frizz!!! The hair dryer is lightweight and not loud even my my two pounds Yorkie likes it and her very long silky hair looks Shiny and soft', I love it would recommend highly.
  1692. After looking for a blow dryer for several weeks and being quite surprised at how much they cost. (I hadn't purchased one in a couple of years.) I could not understand why some of them cost as much as $250! I don't see that the technology is that much different from the less expensive ones. So after reading the reviews on this blowdryer I purchased it and couldn't be happier. I have curly/kinky African-American hair that I must wash every day. I work outside the home so I have to dry my hair every day as well. This dryer is perfect. It doesn't get too hot and fry my hair but it gets hot enough to get it dry quickly. The diffuser attachment fits perfectly and works well. The multiple heat settings are nice for drying my hair closer to my face - I can set it on a lower temperature. This is a fantastic blowdryer. It is lightweight and not very loud. Best deal for the money!

Unfortunately yesterday the blow dryer lost speed and is not sounding too well. Yes, it still has heat and 2 settings, but high now sounds like low and low sounds bad. FYI, I have very thin, fine, short hair, so I do not blow dry my hair for long periods of time. I'm afraid it's days are numbered, shame on me, but I have misplaced the receipt and Revlon will not fix without proof of purchase. I do a lot of research before making purchases and felt this was a very good blow dryer for a mid price. I will head back to the store today to begin the research process again to purchase a new blow dryer. It's clear things are not made as well as they used to be. Hold on to your receipt and the original box, just in case.

  1735. I purchased this hair dryer to replace a Conair retractable cord model that no longer worked. I spent a few days trying to decide between this model and a more expensive (different brand) model but ultimately decided on this one due to the low price and generally favorable reviews. This hair dryer is average -- it does its job but not overly well. The highlights are that it is extremely lightweight, very quiet, and the cord length is more than adequate. Unfortunately, it does not get nearly as hot as my previous hair dryer nor does it blow very hard, even on hot temp and high speed. In fact, I have noticed contrary to what the hair dryer claims, that it indeed takes LONGER to dry my hair. I find myself letting my hair air-dry for 30 minutes or so before using the hair dryer so it doesn't take so long. The ion feature may or may not make a difference. My hair is smoother after using this hair dryer, but that may be because it is more gentle than my previous one by not getting as hot or blowing my hair around. I have two Maltese that get weekly baths, and I would like to note that I LOVE this hair dryer for them. I use the concentrator attachment when I dry them and it works wonderfully. I just wish it had a little more heat and power behind it for use on my long, straight, blonde hair.

This Revlon dryer is about medium power from my experience. I didn't get another Infinity because there had been recalls on it so thought it best to wait, and it was heavy, but I'd rather deal with the weight and have my hair dry faster. I had dropped my old one and it broke. I will probably make do with this one for awhile but I miss my Infinity! This one is very light, it almost feels like a toy. Despite the seemingly weak air coming out it dries in a reasonable amount of time and isn't too frizzy (I usually have to flat iron my hair just to get the pouf down even after drying it straight with a brush).
  1822. I would have given this dryer 5 stars except for 1 thing - the on/off button should be located a little lower. I find myself accidentally turning the dryer off during use sometimes because my thumb hits the button.<br />Otherwise, I love how fast it dries my hair and keeps it from getting frizzy. Also, it is not too heavy.
  1823. This hair dryer has absolutely all the qualities I most desire with three small exceptions: I wish it had a retractable cord, a folding handle, and that it was smaller. Still, this is the best model I have found for a low noise, powerful tourmaline ionic ceramic dryer at the best price!
  1824. Purchased this after my Conair started getting very hot in the handle. I love the way this works. Dries my hair quickly. The only downfall is the switch. It's a flip switch located right on the handle. It's very easy to turn the dryer off while I'm in the middle if drying my hair. But other than that, I love this one!
  1825. Definitely worth it. Good price, good product.

  1862. The unit is nicely made, quiet, and provides enough heat even at it's LOW setting for fast drying of your hair. For $20 I shouldn't complain. But!<br />1) Despite some of the reviews describing it as &#34;compact&#34; this is not a shrinking violet. All opinions related to size are subjective but to me it looks pretty close to units used in saloons. Hopefully this means a larger and longer lasting motor.<br />2) The unit is ONLY 110VAC, despite that it's advertised by Amazon as &#34;it also available for shipping to select countries outside the U.S&#34;.<br />3) The manual is a joke, but it's not funny. (It has footnote &#34;appliance may vary from the illustrations&#34;, but it omits to mention that it may vary from the descriptions as well.)<br />a) voltage selector - doesn't exists. It's a bit late to find this out after you've purchased the item<br />b) Removable end cap /clean the lint filter: &#34;REMOVE IT BY TURNING IT COUNTERCLOCKWISE&#34;.<br /> By all means if you're ready to break it off completely. Mine opens by pressing a hidden latch at the top of the end cap and has a hinge at the bottom that I wasn't brave (or fool) enough to try to force off: &#34;to be washed and cleaned&#34;.

That's never happened to me with any other dryer so perhaps I will try to figure out what the warranty is on this. I do like this dryer a lot though, it's is so lightweight and dries fast.   1884. This is a great hair dryer. I like the buttons on the handle, because they do not get in the way like some other hair dryer buttons do. The setting I like best is Low Heat, with High Power.   1885. Used this less than 20 times and it burned out, smoking....
  1886. I have naturally curly hair which means... naturally frizzy hair, if anything goes wrong which it usually does. I have used an ionic, ceramic hair dryer for a while now. Never noticed a huge difference with that. The improvement from this model is the diffuser. I haven't used other diffusers, so I have no basis of comparison but if you are a curly girl or guy, adding a diffuser to your arsenal is worth it. It's a different way of drying your hair. I'm still adjusting to it-- you place the end of the diffuser against your head in one area and hold it there while it gently puffs air all around it. We're supposed to tousle our hair with the diffuser &#34;fingers&#34; but I mostly bonk myself in the head when I do that-- much better to use the &#34;fingers&#34; to gently cup the end of your hair so it gets scrunched up against your head-- and then hold it there for a minute. Then move on to a new spot on your head. What I've noticed is that my hair curls more evenly than before. I used to have areas that would flatten a bit even with the low speed of a regular blow dryer. You can imagine how lovely that looked. Now all the areas are a bit more uniformly curled and there are fewer flyaways on top. Other blow dryers with diffuser attachments may do the same thing-- this one was a good price and had the ionic/ceramic combo I wanted. I'm very happy with it.<br /><br />One note-- the diffuser is pretty big so you'll need a deeper drawer or a bit more cupboard space to store it.
  1887. much more powerful than my last hair dryer!
  1888. Dried your hair fast! Just as advertised!
  1889. Been using for years. No complaints.

  1909. I have really thick hair and it usually takes a several minutes to dry. This dryer significantly cut my dry time. Lots of air movement and the ionic feature really works. The other suggestion would be to insulate the barrel. I like to hold it when drying the back and you can't on this dryer as it gets way too hot. Still I love this dryer and would purchase again.

  1911. this works great for a blow dryer and was cheap. people think i spent tons of money on it and it looks really cool with all the attachments.
  1912. I needed a hair dryer to use about once or twice a month. I found this at a great price with mostly good reviews so I decided to purchase it. I am transitioning to natural kinky/curly hair and have BSL hair overall. I almost always air dry so i needed something to dry it if I was ever in a hurry. What I was looking for was: at least 1875 Watt dryer, Ionic, Compact, With multiple attachments (at least comb, diffuser and concentrator), Not too loud. This dryer fills all those requirements... except for one thing: no comb-attachment.<br /><br />Since this came with two attachments, I planned to purchase the third one from Revlon. For those unaware, Revlon hair products are licensed to Helen of Troy. I contacted HoT to inquire about which model of comb would fit this dryer, since most comb attachments are expensive and I did not want to waste my money. They were very fast to respond but no one could tell me if there was one available that would fit. After a week, I received an email saying that they do not make a comb attachment that would fit this particular model. They said that this particular dryer has a specific nozzle so no other attachments from them, or other brands would fit it. I was disappointed, since nowhere in the package or description page does it say this. Perhaps I was naive to think that a company would never think not to make other attachments that would fit their best selling economy model, other than the standard out of the box ones. Now I have to think if this dryer was worth it at all. Who wants to buy a separate dryer just for that one extra task?<br /><br />About the product:<br />Pros:<br />lightweight, unbulky overall.<br />Heats up considerably. Warm is an adequate setting for me, but it might be too hot for someone with very fine straight hair.<br />2 attachments, including the concentrator.<br />good value for the price.<br />fast shipping.<br />Medium noise<br /><br />Cons:<br />Cord is too short. Does not rotate easily either.<br />Verycheap plastic, i'm afraid this could melt with heavy prolonged use.<br />Can only be used with the specific attachments that come with it (2), which are not for sale separately (If you contact Helen of Troy they might send you some for free if yours break)<br />Diffuser is a joke. Not long enough for long hair to dry effectively. The fingers are too short and it's not concave so the hot air just stays in the surface. People's heads are nor flat, Revlon!<br /><br />Conclusion:<br />If you use your hair dryer very often, for long periods of time uninterrupted, this might die on you. If you use it very irregularly it's a good balance between the price and use. If you want to use other attachments other than the ones that come with it, you might be out of luck. If you are purchasing this solely for the diffuser, I would stay away from this. Would I purchase this again if it broke down? No, I wouldn't, but it will do for the time being.

  1942. I've bought and returned a few hair dryers now in my quest for the perfect one for my hair, which is really good when i do a little work on it. My requirements are simple - ionic, tourmaline, powerful when you want and gentle when you want, reasonably sized and light weight. This dryer perfectly fit the bill, ended my long-lasting quest and finally I have MY hair dryer! Update 4/19/11 - Three years have passed, my hair is now waist-length (beautiful, but more work) and this hair dryer still rocks! I've recommended it to many friends and they've all loved it. I thought $30 was inexpensive (that was what I paid when I bought it) but friends have bought it for almost half that prize on Amazon during this period. It's just awesome that you can get such a great product for such a low price. Seriously - go for it!

  2077. I found this to be a great hair dryer. There is a design flaw that because of how annoying it is, I've taken off 2 stars. I had this hairdryer and when it finally died, I immediately ordered a new one. The new one has temp and air select buttons that toggle back and forth as opposed to the older model that we would push up and down for heat and air. Believe it or not, it makes all the difference in the world. I can't tell you how many times during drying my hair that just by switching hands to do one side of my hair or the other, in doing so, the heat temperature toggles down from hot to warm. This happens, of course, because the switches are located directly where our fingers grab the handle. When it had switches, I'd have to consciously slide the switch up or down. With the toggles, it happens accidentally all the time. I need the temp to be on hot because I have curly hair and the heat dries it on the straighter side for me. Warm temp causes my hair to not dry completely and tends to frizz. So I am always on the alert to keep an eye on the heat selection as I'm drying my hair. An unnecessary step as far as I'm concerned. It wasn't an improvement, but rather an impediment. It's really too bad. It was a great dryer. Now that the second one has conked out, I'm making sure I check the kinds of switches that are on any I am considering buying.
  2078. my wife loves this thing! it was a Christmas present and she still finds new ways she can do her hair! perfect price, easy to use

  2085. As someone who washes and styles her hair on a daily basis, I have always paid outrageous prices for hair dryers that were advertised as &#34;professional&#34; and &#34;the best one on the market.&#34; (thinking that if a professional beautician used the product for heavy duty daily use, it would surely meet my non-professional needs) This usually resulted in my spending in the $150 - $200 dollar range.<br />These dryers, universally, were sleek and HEAVY. Most lasted, however, no more than a year. Last month, when my lasted model started smoking, necessitating shopping for a new model, I called my beautician and put in an order for a model which would have cost approximately $170.00. Happily there was a delay in getting that dryer and I shopped on the Amazon site for a quick replacement.<br /> To my total surprise, I read the reviews for the Revlon Tourmaline Ionic Ceramic Dryer and decided that since it was S0-O-O inexpensive, I would give it a try. AMAZINGLY, it is light, powerful and totally wonderful!! It does everything as advertised (truly unusual these days) and even if I have to replace it more often, it is so reasonably priced that I can have a new one every few months for the prices I was paying for those I have used over the years. I am truly a VERY HAPPY CAMPER!!!

  2172. If I remember correctly it doesn't say the voltage on device, and the plug has a fuse on it which leads you to believe it's duel voltage. However, when I plugged it into a socket in Hong Kong, it literally Exploded. Dumped in the trash, totally useless. Fuse went up in flames and I didn't have the ability to replace the plug at the time to see if I could get it to work again. Might have been a good dryer otherwise, despite being quite large and plastic feeling.<br /><br />Pros: works on 110 volts, if you only have 110 volt outlets and never travel that's fine.<br />Cons: no voltage switching = plug it into a 220 volt socket and your outlet is going to go up like a flash bang weapon.<br /><br />It worked well as a hair dryer before I went traveling. I wish they would have had a warning considering how common dual voltage is these days. I have similar products and travel a lot and this is the FIRST and only product I've ever had a problem with. I've never had anything go up in flames like this. Considering how much I travel I wouldn't have bought it had I known.<br /><br />I knocked it down to 3 stars because I really feel like it should have stated the voltage clearly, or that it was not dual voltage. it would have saved me from purchasing this, or at least accidentally destroy it, which could have potentially caused damage to my apartment as well. Although it otherwise may be a capable dryer, there is no way I can rate this highly because I see this as a huge lack of over-site and dangerous flaw for electronics these days. I ultimately had to throw it away.<br /><br />Like I said, this might seem trivial if you live in the US and never left the country but it will be a show stopper for some.

So after another $12, I'm out a total of $33 to wait weeks to get yet another &#34;new&#34; hairdryer that will hopefully last......how long?? This has been eye-opening! It easily took half the drying time with this new Revlon. On high, it has a very strong blast of air and it quickly got my hair dry. On high it is hard to style with a brush, so I mostly finger dry. My hair definitely feels softer and smoother. I used to air dry most of the time b/c I felt like it was less stress on my color-treated hair. Not anymore - my hair looks and feels better when I use this dryer. I do have to use a flat iron after drying it, but that's just a fact I've accepted in life. Definitely recommend it for people with thick hair and/or frizz. It is a longer nozzle than my previous dryer so I've whacked myself in the head a few times. It will just take some getting used to.

With my old dryer, I used the diffuser with the heat level on high and the fan speed on low, and my hair dried. This dryer takes forever to dry with the same settings. The first one was a Vidal Sassoon that had ionic technology, but didn't get near hot enough. She was drying her hair for > 20 minutes.<br /><br />The second attempt was the Revlon RV469 ceramic, which was much quieter and got hotter, but didn't have much air flow. Also, it is quite heavy. It was better than the first dryer, but not hair drying nirvana.<br /><br />This dryer (Revlon RV544) has easily cut my wife's drying time in half. She has very thick & long hair, and the high heat setting makes quick work of it. It gets hot enough that I actually tone it down to warm for myself (I have short, thick hair) whenever I have to use the dryer. I think the air flow settings are perfect.   2559. Do not purchase this! A quick look at the other 1-star and 2-star reviews should tell you what you need to know, as this thing has apparently caused TONS of sparking and even flaming incidents. (I searched the reviews for the word &#34;fire&#34; and got 84 results, some dating back to 2011.) Mine was in use for about a year and a half before it became temperamental. In the middle of drying my hair, it would shut off for a second, but changing angles or adjusting the cord where it meets the unit solved the problem temporarily, so I kept using it while starting to think about a replacement. In retrospect, I should have stopped using it immediately at the first sign of a problem. After a week or so of this temperamental behavior, the thing suddenly popped really loud and made a HUGE spark, causing me to drop it and jump back, thinking I was about to be burned and/or electrocuted. I have GFCI protected outlets plus the similar protection on the unit, but it didn't matter. I return here and see a ton of people reporting similar issues (again, 84 results for the word &#34;fire&#34; in these reviews, and well over a hundred results for &#34;spark&#34;!). This thing should be pulled immediately; it's absurd that this many people have been reporting problems for this long and yet they're still being sold. I reported it to saferproducts.gov, Amazon, and Revlon. Others who've had issues should do the same. Amazon assured me they'd stop selling while they investigated, but they never did. It's appalling that the many reports already here are apparently not yet enough to motivate anyone to take responsible action to prevent injuries. If you insist on purchasing one, all I can say is take some screenshots of all these reports for your lawsuit.

A cupped diffuser is better. Overall, it's okay as far as a unit that will dry your hair, but don't expect anything else but that. It is lightweight, so I gave it 3 stars for living up to that description.

  2569. I have had this for 2 years now and use it almost every day. Its not too loud, still works great, easy to hold in hand, has the bonus piece, good price and good setting, hot, warm, cold and low/high. Works perfectly fine as should and I have no complaints with product.
  2570. The product was exactly has described in the description and I would recommend this product as a general use blow dryer.
  2571. This blowdryer has the best diffuser attachment I've ever purchased. It really diffuses so all you get is heat, no blowing around of the hair, so the curls keep their shape better. Also, for some reason it's hotter than my old 1875 watt dryer, so my hair dries more quickly. Unlike other reviewers, I have the same amount of frizz as I did with my old dryer-- the ion part just doesn't do anything for me. But the curls are better shaped because the diffuser prevents them from being blown around. The one negative is that the on-off switch is on the handle right where you hold the blowdryer, so it pokes your hand and you end up occasionally turning it off by accident. To avoid this you can hold it lower down on the handle but that's awkward. Nonetheless, I would completely recommend this dryer, especially if you have curly hair.

  2574. I never thought that just a hair dryer could make such a difference until I tried this one! Had it shipped next day air because I was so anxious to try it. Let me tell you, the reviews definitely prevailed on this one! Hands down the best blow out I have ever had in my entire life, including salon visits! Usually takes me about 45 minutes to blow dry and style my short bob haircut, with this little gem it took 15 minutes!! I didn't even need to use my straightener to smooth out the ends. Super lightweight too! Can't beat the quality and price. Seriously best purchase I have ever made on Amazon!
  2575. I actually bought this hair dryer from another site, but thought I would share my experience here now that I'm looking for a new hair dryer...again... I was pretty happy with the power, heat, and weight of the dryer at first use. My hair is chin length and straight, so only takes about 10-15 minutes to style from start to finish. Within the first week I started to notice that the dryer nozzle was starting to melt around the rim. I only use the concentrator attachment for the last few minutes of styling, and noticed that it also started bubbling and quickly burnt big holes on either side of the attachment. The dryer doesn't get as hot as a lot of them out there, so I'm kinda baffled by this. It's actually the first time I've ever seen it happen on any dryer I've ever used. Long story short, I expected the dryer to last longer than just under two months. If I had it to do over I would put the $20 towards another good quality hair dryer that won't end up looking like some weird melted mess. Very poor quality and not worth $20.

It wasn't the plug - trying this at different outlets yielded the same result. This was annoying, but it seemed that if I pointed the dryer in a certain direction and didn't move, it would continue to blow. Then, finally, it got so bad that drying my hair was impossible - the blow dryer was stopping more than it was blowing. I expected it to last for longer than a year, so overall, the purchase was a disappointment.

I don't use the cold shot button - I never liked that button on any hair dryer - it's too much of pain to hold down and move the dryer around at the same time, especially if you want it a little warm, but it's there for those who do like it.<br />~The buttons can be a little in the way of holding the dryer, but it's not enough of a deterrent for me not to love the dryer.<br />~I personally like the little holder on the bottom, that's how I put it away - hanging upside down.   2593. After my old OLD hair dryer bit it, I started hunting around for a big-girl dryer that wouldn't break the bank. I had been using a cheapy-McCheaperson dryer (that I've had since childhood--d'oh!), so I didn't think I could get something worse for my hair than that thing anyway!<br /><br />I have long, very fine hair that goes static crazy when it's dry out. While I didn't notice it at first, now that I think about it, my hair is not as static-y as it used to be. I also don't seem to notice as much damage to my hair as I used to, especially when it comes to split ends. However, I've also started to take better care of my hair than I used to and I now use preventative products such as a heat protectant and a tiny bit of Argan oil to help protect and maintain hair health, so while I've noticed hair improvement, I have no idea if it's from the hair products, the dryer, or both (I designed a very poor scientific experiment--too many variables. Sorry!). As far as dry time, I don't think I notice much of a difference, but my hair is very fine and I don't have much of it to begin with, so if my drying time was cut from 6 to 5 minutes, I wouldn't notice. I don't use the concentrator or the diffusor, so I can't comment on those. However, the dryer doesn't seem overly noisy or heavy, which I like, especially for the technology that's packed inside. I've also noticed that my boyfriend uses it every once in a while, and he never did that with my old one, so maybe it's sleek and cool looking enough that he reaches for it now? Hah, I have no idea! I also haven't had any problems with the buttons being in the wrong place, or anything like that. I wish it had a swivel and/or retractable cord, but it's not the end of the world that it doesn't. However, take note that those features are lacking if that is important to you!<br /><br />Overall, I haven't had the amazing experience that others have had with this dryer, but I think it's more due to the thinness and fineness of my hair. I haven't had any negative experiences, just haven't been blown away (har har) like some others have. I'd still recommend this dryer to others, as it's a decent dryer for the tech that's packed inside, even if those bonuses don't seem to change my hair's life!

I have mid-length, very curly, color treated hair that I style smooth and then finish with a flat iron so power that won't fry my hair or make my hair frizzy is important to me.   2945. I bought this dryer from Amazon at the end of Dec. 2012, used it about once a week, and now after being on for about 30 seconds, the RESET button pops out and the dryer turns off.<br /><br />With over four hundred 5 star reviews, I did not read the lower ratings thinking that it MUST be a great dryer because so many people think so. Hopefully my \\"5 star\\" review will get you to read the 1 star reviews. This dryer has had this same problem for years and \\"Revlon\\" has not addressed it. Maybe because only a small number of dryers end up smoking, sparking, catching on fire they don't acknowledge it is a real problem. This is what Whirlpool has been doing for years and why there is now a class action suit - their Whirlpool, Kenmore, Maytag, and Kitchen Aid dishwashers have resulted in many fires, but they have a video online explaining that since most of the fires are contained inside the machine, they do not feel there is a problem! Google dishwasher fires before you ever set yours to run while you are sleeping!<br /><br />I realize that this was not a real 5 star review and that it should not have also reviewed dishwashers at the same time, but if only one person avoids a fire with either product I think it is a good review.

So, I haven't used this much but I have noticed this winter that the hair dryer is awfully weak (I keep thinking the power is on low, but it's as high as it can go). I'd definitely recommend a higher powered hairdryer.

  2969. This is an update for anyone considering buying this hair dryer. I purchased it in 2011 and after about 18 months of use I started to experience problems with the cord at the juncture with the appliance, which caused sparking and smoking as stated in some of the previous reviews. Up until this point the performance had been awesome, and it was by far the best hair dryer that I had ever owned. I contacted Revlon about the issue and they referred me to Helen of Troy, the company that manufactures this particular item for them. Helen of Troy immediately sent me a replacement, and I was thrilled to see that the new appliance has been redesigned and the problem corrected. If you are having any reservations about buying this item due to some of the previous negative reviews, please be assured that the issue has been addressed and the problem resolved.

  2981. I have three teenage daughters so recently I purchased three different hair dryers from Amazon. Imagine my surprise when I realized two were essentially identical except for the price, the length of the cord and the \\"brand\\" name. The Pro Beauty Tools 5885 Professional Lightweight Hair Dryer is the exact same as the Revlon RV544 1875 Watt Tourmaline Ionic Lightweight Dryer, Silver/Black by Revlon. Both of these hair dryers are made by Helen of Troy. Both have the same handle, body, and heat/speed options. Both have the exact same Intertek number (3175842). The major difference is the Pro Beauty Tools hair dryer does have a cord that is 2' longer than the Revlon dryer and it (the Pro Beauty Tools) has an extra filter included. For the $10 difference in price (Pro Beauty Tools higher) one can decide if these options are worth the extra cash. In my opinion both of these items are a FIVE STAR item for price and performance.
